messages.subject: Re: Only if you are brave
messages.msgSnippet: ... I think I ve mentioned this one before, but, hey, a little bit of stupidity can go a long way.  Once when leaving a hotel with three swords wrapped up in a
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@w...> wrote:
> fess up, what is the dumbest thing you have done with a blade.

I think I've mentioned this one before, but, hey, a little bit of
stupidity can go a long way. Once when leaving a hotel with three
swords wrapped up in a towel, as I reached for the front door handle,
I inadvertantly tilted the upper tsuka ends down, and a wak started
sliding out of its saya onto the marble floor. I made a wild grab for
it with my free hand, and got it - or, better said, it got me. The ha
near the habaki sliced vertically into the middle of my thumb, about a
third of the way up my fingernail. The towel came in handy.

NC

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Only if you are brave
messages.msgSnippet: Practicing ipponme, during the draw, I cut into the fleshy part of my thumb, not too deep, but nonetheless, lots of blood. Could ve been worse, but boy, did I
messages.messageBody:
Practicing ipponme, during the draw, I cut into the fleshy part of my
thumb, not too deep, but nonetheless, lots of blood. Could've been
worse, but boy, did I feel stupid.

Best Regards,

Andres

At 05:50 AM 12/5/2005, you wrote:
>Greetings all, I was chatting with my good mate Paul B, and imparting on
>him, the woeful evening I had last Thursday. To fill you in, I was
>attacked by a cat. Now I know, but stop laughing, it's not that funny.
>The cat has the second most disgusting mouth ( bacteria etc. ) in the
>world ( Milt and Pete Klein will know the first ) and it managed to
>damage the 3rd metacarpal and ruptured a vein. It was a bad bite. My
>hand blew up to the size of a bag of tsuba and is still extremely sore,
>with only limited ability to make a fist. I have endure cats teeth,
>tetiness needles and antibiotics for 5 days.
>
>So with that information, Paul and I got to discussing what I should
>have been telling my clients and friends, trying to explain away the
>large bandage with bravardo, things like an 8 foot dog tried to eat me,
>or I lost a fight with the lawn mower ( I actually did that once ) when
>Paul suggested, I should have said I sliced it with a sword.
>
>So good folk.......... fess up, what is the dumbest thing you have done
>with a blade.
>
>I of course have never done anything stupid with a sword, though I did
>whack myself in the eye with a large Heianjo tsuba once. Come on, don't
>be shy.
>
>cheers
>
>Rich

messages.subject: Re: Only if you are brave
messages.msgSnippet: fess up, what is the dumbest thing you have done ... I held up my koto Gassan katana and yelled like an idiot when the Bulls won the NBA Championship the first
messages.messageBody:
fess up, what is the dumbest thing you have done
> with a blade.


I held up my koto Gassan katana and yelled like an idiot when the Bulls
won the NBA Championship the first time, sliced and popped a balloon
floating in the air ( Not an easy feat, trust me ).


milt

messages.subject: Only if you are brave
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings all, I was chatting with my good mate Paul B, and imparting on him, the woeful evening I had last Thursday. To fill you in, I was attacked by a cat.
messages.messageBody:
Greetings all, I was chatting with my good mate Paul B, and imparting on
him, the woeful evening I had last Thursday. To fill you in, I was
attacked by a cat. Now I know, but stop laughing, it's not that funny.
The cat has the second most disgusting mouth ( bacteria etc. ) in the
world ( Milt and Pete Klein will know the first ) and it managed to
damage the 3rd metacarpal and ruptured a vein. It was a bad bite. My
hand blew up to the size of a bag of tsuba and is still extremely sore,
with only limited ability to make a fist. I have endure cats teeth,
tetiness needles and antibiotics for 5 days.

So with that information, Paul and I got to discussing what I should
have been telling my clients and friends, trying to explain away the
large bandage with bravardo, things like an 8 foot dog tried to eat me,
or I lost a fight with the lawn mower ( I actually did that once ) when
Paul suggested, I should have said I sliced it with a sword.

So good folk.......... fess up, what is the dumbest thing you have done
with a blade.

I of course have never done anything stupid with a sword, though I did
whack myself in the eye with a large Heianjo tsuba once. Come on, don't
be shy.

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: have been collecting information - off the track a bit
messages.msgSnippet: off the track a bit, Alan how do you get Kanji to show up in these threads, I have tried and tried..... Cheers Rich ... -- *Richard Turner - Nihonto Message
messages.messageBody:
off the track a bit, Alan how do you get Kanji to show up in these
threads, I have tried and tried.....

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, The mei on page 313 are of Ito Masaharu and they do not look much like the signature on your tsuba, Haynes has more makers listed as I would expect
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,
The mei on page 313 are of Ito Masaharu and they do not look much like the
signature on your tsuba, Haynes has more makers listed as I would expect
although I have found artists in Toso Kinko Jiten that aren't in Haynes. One
thing to remember is that some makers used 正 & 政 interchangeably and I am
sure not all of these makers are recorded as doing so.

Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, The mei on page 313 are of Ito Masaharu and they do not look much like the signature on your tsuba, Haynes has more makers listed as I would expect
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,
The mei on page 313 are of Ito Masaharu and they do not look much like the
signature on your tsuba, Haynes has more makers listed as I would expect
although I have found artists in Toso Kinko Jiten that aren't in Haynes. One
thing to remember is that some makers used the two common forms of 'Masa'
interchangeably.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information
messages.msgSnippet: Haynes 2:847-848: MASAHARU H 03892.0 Family: Ito Name: Masaharo Zenzaemon Worked: Odawara ju, Sagami Province and Bushu ju Date: ca. 1750-1800 Notes:
messages.messageBody:
Haynes 2:847-848:

MASAHARU
H 03892.0

Family: Ito
Name: Masaharo Zenzaemon
Worked: Odawara ju, Sagami Province and Bushu ju
Date: ca. 1750-1800
Notes: considered the second master of the Ito Odawara school branch of the Ito school. Student of Ito Masatane H 04528. Furukawa catalog pl. 19 #107
Sources: Wakayama Takeshi, Toso Kinko Jiten 355 -L -10, 380 -L -4.

Wakayama Takeshi, Toso Kodogy Meiji Yaikei, 1-313.

Ken'ichi Kokubo Shinsen Kinko Meikan, 345, 371.

(kanji omitted, abbreviations expanded)
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, December 03, 2005 1:16 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information


Hi Alan, thank you. I am currently remedying that Haynes issue :-). I
have the Toso Kodogu Meiji Taikei and thought all those mei were the Ito
artist ?. There are about a dozen in the Toso Kinko Jiten but ony one I
can see related to Bushu...... I also don't have the Kinko Meikan, opps,
thats too books.

Rich


Alan Bale wrote:

>Sorry to bear bad news, see Toso Kodogu Meiji Taikei volume 1 page 313 for
>pictures, I don't have Kinko Meikan at the moment so I don't know if he is
>in that book.
>Alan
>
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>
>To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
>Sent: Friday, December 02, 2005 10:46 PM

>>>

pictures, I don't have Kinko Meikan at the moment so I don't know if he is

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information
messages.msgSnippet: The signature does not look like that of Ito Masaharu also the shape of the tsuba suggests to me that it is mid 19th century, there were according to Haynes
messages.messageBody:
The signature does not look like that of Ito Masaharu also the shape of the
tsuba suggests to me that it is mid 19th century, there were according to
Haynes book three other Masaharu in Edo c.1850 that could fit, two of whom
signed 'Bushu ju Masaharu'.
Alan

From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Ron. Masaharu was renowned according to Nihonto Koza Kodogu for his Nikubori and Ji Sukashi Kusabana ( grasses and flowers ) tsuba. nearly all of his
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Ron. Masaharu was renowned according to Nihonto Koza Kodogu for
his Nikubori and Ji Sukashi Kusabana ( grasses and flowers ) tsuba.
nearly all of his work I have in my library are of a floral motif.

it's a different tsuba for me taste wise, though I have taken a bit of a
fancy to it LOL.

best

Rich




Ron Hartmann wrote:

>Certainly an interesting motif. I'm not familiar enough with Masaharu to know if this is unique for him or not but I'll take your word for it. Nice tsuba!
>
>Ron
>STL
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information
messages.msgSnippet: Certainly an interesting motif. I m not familiar enough with Masaharu to know if this is unique for him or not but I ll take your word for it. Nice tsuba! Ron
messages.messageBody:
Certainly an interesting motif. I'm not familiar enough with Masaharu to know if this is unique for him or not but I'll take your word for it. Nice tsuba!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 4:42 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] I have been collecting information


on Bushû tsuba I have, signed Bushû jû MASAHARU. It is fairly
interesting and I thought I would share. This style of work is not
typical of MASAHARU. I wonder if it was a custom order ?

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/bushu_masaharu.html

cheers

Richard Turner
